topic: U.S. Reaches Devastating 1 Million Deaths From COVID-19
content: Reporter, HuffPost The nation has reached a heartbreaking milestone of 1 million confirmed deaths from COVID-19 since the coronavirus pandemic began over two years ago. An average of over 300 people are still dying each day from COVID-19 â€” most of whom are unvaccinated â€” even as safe and effective vaccines have been available to prevent severe illness or death from the virus. â€œWe mark a tragic milestone: one million American lives lost to COVID-19,â€ President Joe Biden said in a statement on Thursday, ordering flags to be flown at half-staff at the White House and other federal grounds. â€œEach an irreplaceable loss. Each leaving behind a family, a community, and a nation forever changed because of this pandemic.â€ The president asked Americans to â€œremain vigilant against this pandemic and do everything we can to save as many lives as possible.â€ Although hospitalization and death rates from COVID-19 have fallen from their winter peak, new cases have begun to rise again, doubling since April, as highly contagious omicron subvariants spread across the country and hospitalizations are ticking back up. Some 22% â€” or nearly 1 in 4 â€” people nationwide have still not gotten a single dose of a vaccine against the coronavirus, according to Centers for Disease Control and Prevention data. About one-third â€” or 33% â€” of the population has not been fully vaccinated with two doses of Pfizerâ€™s or Modernaâ€™s vaccines or the single dose of Johnson & Johnsonâ€™s. And about half of people eligible for a booster â€” which health experts say provides the best protection against the latest variants â€” have not gotten theirs. Throughout the deadly pandemic, right-wing media pundits have spread misinformation on the vaccinesâ€™ safety and effectiveness, and Republican lawmakers and officials have fought efforts to mandate vaccines for workers. CDC Director Rochelle Walensky noted in February that unvaccinated people were 14 times more likely to die from COVID-19 than those who are vaccinated and boosted. Meanwhile, federal and state-level guidelines have dramatically loosened virus-related restrictions in recent months, with many states lifting mask mandates for schools and a court ruling ending a national mask mandate for planes and other travel. (The CDC still recommends masking on planes, trains and buses.) People with disabilities have warned that the millions of Americans with chronic health conditions, including those who are immunocompromised or have heart or respiratory issues, are still vulnerable to severe illness from COVID-19. Throughout the pandemic, Black and Latinx people have faced disproportionate hospitalization and death from the virus, as these communities are overrepresented among front-line workers, in industries like agriculture or in the service sector, where employees arenâ€™t able to work from home as the virus spreads. Black and Latinx people are more than twice as likely as white people to be hospitalized with the virus, and nearly twice as likely to die from it. Reporter, HuffPost

topic: U.S. Cities Step Up Their COVID Guidance, But Stop Short Of Imposing Mandates
content: Breaking News Reporter, HuffPost Cities and health agencies across the country are stepping up their recommendations for measures to limit the spread of COVID-19, but stopping short of imposing sweeping mandates. The measures come as the omicron subvariant BA.2.12.1 continues to spread in the country, almost overtaking BA.2, according to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention for the week ending on May 14. The New York City Commissioner of Health and Mental Hygiene issued an advisory Monday calling on people to mask up in indoor places, including stores and offices, irrespective of vaccination status, as cases have been steadily rising and â€œincreasing pressure on the health system.â€ Still, Eric Adams, New York Cityâ€™s mayor, is not mandating the wearing of face masks. â€œWe are not at the point of doing anything other than urging New Yorkers, while you are indoors in large settings, social settings, wear your masks,â€ Adams said, according to The New York Times. â€œIf there comes a time that our hospitals are in a state of emergency, or weâ€™re trending that way, and my doctors that run the hospitals tell me this is what we need to do, Iâ€™m going to listen to them,â€ he continued. Los Angeles is also facing similar pressures, as COVID-positive hospitalizations are trending upward in Los Angeles County, rising by 29% compared to last week, according to the Los Angeles Times. On Monday, Barbara Ferrer, the countyâ€™s public health director, also called on people to wear masks in closed spaces to limit the â€œspread while we continue to increase the numbers of residents and workers up to date with their vaccinations,â€ in a statement reported in the LA Times. Both New York City and LA County continue to require masks on public transportation. The CDC is also now recommending testing before domestic travel, no more than three days before the date of the trip, without citing different guidance for fully vaccinated passengers. The Biden administration is also doubling the COVID tests households are allowed to order at home for free. Households will now be able to order up to eight at-home rapid tests. The White Houseâ€™s announcement on testing also took a jab at Congress for failing to pass COVID funding, warning this may compromise the nationâ€™s preparedness to deal with the pandemic. â€œDue to Congressâ€™s failure to provide additional funding for the nationâ€™s COVID-19 response, the Administration cannot continue making the types of federal investments needed to sustain domestic testing manufacturing capacity, and this may jeopardize the federal governmentâ€™s ability to provide free tests moving forward,â€ the statement read. Dr. Ashish Jha, the White Houseâ€™s COVID-19 response coordinator, acknowledged the rise in infections and encouraged people to take a rapid COVID test before attending parties and before visiting vulnerable family members. â€œWeâ€™ve worked hard to get these tests and with cases rising, itâ€™s a good time to get more out to Americans,â€ he tweeted Tuesday. Going to a large gathering? Use rapid tests to not be the person who brings COVID to the partyVisiting a vulnerable relative? Use rapids tests to keep them safeWe've worked hard to get these tests and with cases rising, its a good time to get more out to Americans The White House COVID-19 response team and public health officials, including Dr. Jha, the presidentâ€™s chief medical adviser Dr. Anthony Fauci and CDC Director Dr. Rochelle Walensky, will hold a press briefing Wednesday to provide updates on the countryâ€™s response to the pandemic. President Joe Biden marked the grim milestone of 1 million COVID deaths last week. â€œWe must remain vigilant against this pandemic and do everything we can to save as many lives as possible,â€ Biden said. Breaking News Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Twitter Users Mock Matt Gaetz's 1st Tweet After His Pardon Request Is Made Public
content:
Senior Reporter, HuffPost Rep. Matt Gaetz (R-Fla.) became a victim of â€œpardon bombingâ€ Thursday on Twitter. It happened after the House select committee investigating the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol revealed that the lawmaker was one of at least five members of Congress who attempted to get pardons from then-President Donald Trump for their roles in helping Trump attempt to overturn the 2020 presidential election. But Gaetz wanted his pardon to be a lot broader than his role in Trumpâ€™s election fraud, according to Cassidy Hutchinson, a former aide to White House chief of staff Mark Meadows. She told the committee that Gaetz had been pushing for a pardon since early December, according to Business Insider. Former White House senior adviser Eric Herschmann told the committee that the â€œgeneral toneâ€ of the pardon request revolved around the idea that â€œWe may get prosecuted because we were defensive of, you know, the presidentâ€™s positions on these things.â€ However, Herschmann noted that the pardon Gaetz was angling for may have been intended to also protect him from the sex trafficking investigation swirling around him. â€œThe pardon that he was discussing, requesting, was as broad as you could describe, from... the beginning of time up until today, for any and all things,â€ Herschmann told the committee. After the revelation, Gaetz posted on Twitter to accuse the committee of being â€œan unconstitutional political sideshowâ€ that is â€œrapidly losing the interest of the American people and now resorts to siccing federal law enforcement on political opponents.â€ The January 6 Committee is an unconstitutional political sideshow. It is rapidly losing the interest of the American people and now resorts to siccing federal law enforcement on political opponents. Many Twitter users responded with variations on the same joke. I beg your pardon? Pardon me? Beg your pardon?@RepAndyBiggsAZ @Jim_Jordan@RepMTG@RepMoBrooks@RepMattGaetz @RepGosar @replouiegohmert@RepScottPerry Pardon me? Traitor says what? Others pointed out that innocent people rarely request pardons. Wow. Congressmen helping Trump on & before 1/6 & then demanding pardons. Makes me think of 18 USC 201: A public official who corruptly seeks anything of value in return for an official act or colluding in fraud shall be imprisoned for up to 15 years & disqualified from office Hi Matt. Why did you ask for a pardon? Cheers ğŸ» You sought a pardon because you knew you committed a crime, helping Trump try to overturn the election.Sit down. https://t.co/jNzth4P0m2 You asked for a pardon, and now the DOJ will impolitely ask you to head to your cell, Matt. One person had a pertinent question for the congressman. Beg your pardon, Matt, do you take Venmo? pic.twitter.com/WyeVsMR92d Senior Reporter, HuffPost Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost?

topic: Angry Trump Again Demands The Impossible From Jan. 6 Panel After Riveting Hearing
content:
Trends Reporter, HuffPost Former President Donald Trumpâ€™s reaction Thursday to another powerful day of testimony before the House select committee investigating the U.S. Capitol riot was to again demand the impossible: evidence of a rigged presidential election. â€œThe only thing not discussed by the Unselects, in any way, shape, or form, is the irrefutable evidence of massive and totally pervasive ELECTION FRAUD & IRREGULARITIES which took place during the 2020 Presidential Election. They refuse to go there,â€ he posted. It wasnâ€™t discussed because it never happened. A litany of testimony from former Department of Justice officials on Thursday â€” and in earlier sessions â€” refuted Trumpâ€™s â€œirrefutableâ€ claims. Trump appears to be ignoring the information in the hearings the same way he ignored responses from his Justice Department, various state officials and U.S. Attorney General William Barr: The claims of a rigged election were baseless. A number of specific claims have been refuted in detail. Trump insisted on Truth Social that it would be â€œimpossibleâ€ for the Jan. 6 hearing to â€œrefute or challenge that which would be put before them. To the Unselects, I ask, LET US PUT ON THE EVIDENCE STATE BY STATE.â€ Neither he nor his supporters have offered any such evidence. Arizona House Speaker Rusty Bowers (R) testified Tuesday that Trump lawyer Rudy Giuliani asked him to hold up electoral votes because â€œ200,000 illegal immigrantsâ€ and more than 5,000 â€œdead peopleâ€ voted in the state. Bowers told Giuliani he wanted names and was promised he would get them, he said. Despite repeated requests, he was never given a single name, Bowers testified. Last week, Trump noted on Truth Social that the â€œUnselect Committee refuses to debate the Election results, the reason for the massive crowd on January 6th, because they canâ€™t.â€ In a separate post Thursday, Trump asked: â€œWhat about the massive ballot stuffing shown ... by the highly respected and credible Patriots of Truth (2000 Mules).â€ He was referring to a discredited â€œdocumentary,â€ which elicited a derisive laugh from the former attorney general during Barrâ€™s testimony. â€œI suppose thatâ€™s OK by the Unselects? Such lies!â€ Trump added in his post. Trends Reporter, HuffPost Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost?

topic: At Least 5 Members Of Congress Asked Trump For Pardons, According To Jan. 6 Committee
content:
Senior Reporter, HuffPost Senior Politics Reporter, HuffPost WASHINGTON â€• The House select committee investigating the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol named five additional Republican Congress members who sought pardons from President Donald Trump. The requests stemmed from their involvement in Trumpâ€™s schemes to try to subvert the 2020 presidential election, which Trump insisted he won despite losing by several million votes. The committee previously revealed that Rep. Scott Perry (R-Pa.) sought a presidential pardon, something the congressman denied. During Thursdayâ€™s public hearing on Capitol Hill, witnesses close to the Trump White House said in previously recorded interviews that Republican Reps. Matt Gaetz (Fla.), Mo Brooks (Ala.), Andy Biggs (Ariz.) and Louie Gohmert (Texas) also asked for pardons. â€œThe pardon he was requesting was as broad as you can describe ... for any and all things,â€ former Trump White House lawyer Eric Herschmann said of Gaetz in video testimony that the committee played on Thursday. Cassidy Hutchinson, an aide to former White House chief of staff Mark Meadows, confirmed to the committee that Gaetz and the other GOP members of Congress sought pardons. â€œMr. Gaetz and Mr. Brooks I know both advocated for there to be a blanket pardon,â€ Hutchinson said. In a statement after the hearing, a spokesperson for Brooks said the congressman only wanted a pardon in case Democrats abused the justice system and started â€œprosecuting and jailingâ€ their political opponents. Brooks also released an image of the email he sent to the White House in December, on behalf of himself and Gaetz, recommending that the president give â€œgeneral (all purpose) pardonsâ€ to every Republican who voted to overturn the election after the Jan. 6 riot. In a speech at Trumpâ€™s rally before the attack on the U.S. Capitol, Brooks said, â€œToday is the day American patriots start taking down names and kicking ass.â€ Hutchinson said that she heard Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-Ga.) also asked for a pardon but that she didnâ€™t hear it directly. â€œI heard that she asked the White House counselâ€™s office for a pardon,â€ she said. â€œThe only reason I know to ask for a pardon is because you think youâ€™ve committed a crime,â€ Jan. 6 committee member Adam Kinzinger (R-Ill.) said. In a tweet after the hearing, Greene didnâ€™t exactly deny that she had asked for a pardon but said, â€œSaying â€˜I heardâ€™ means you donâ€™t know. Spreading gossip and lies is exactly what the January 6th Witch Hunt Committee is all about.â€ Thursdayâ€™s hearing featured testimony from former Justice Department officials Jeffrey Rosen and Richard Donoghue, as well as Office of Legal Counsel director Steven Engel, who described Trumpâ€™s efforts to throw out the election despite their objections that doing so would be unconstitutional and contrary to the will of the American voters. Donoghue, who was then acting deputy attorney general, testified that when Trump threatened to replace Rosen as the acting attorney general with Jeffrey Clark, an assistant attorney general in the departmentâ€™s Environment and Natural Resources Division, he was told the change would spark mass resignations in the Justice Department. â€œMr. President, I would resign immediately. I would not work one minute for this guy,â€ Donoghue said he told Trump, referring to Clark. During the Jan. 6 committee hearing, Kinzinger described how Perry lobbied the White House to elevate Clark in the Justice Department in order to gain his help in subverting the election. Perry improperly brought Clark to a White House meeting and texted White House chief of staff Mark Meadows, urging him to appoint Clark to a role with â€œthe authority to enforce what needs to be done.â€ Perry denied seeking a pardon earlier this month. â€œThe notion that I ever sought a Presidential pardon for myself or other Members of Congress is an absolute, shameless, and soulless lie,â€ Perry said on Twitter. Kinzinger deliberately juxtaposed testimony about pardon-seekers with the live testimony from Justice Department officials who refused to do Trumpâ€™s bidding. â€œThey knew that every bit of what they did was a lie and it was wrong,â€ Kinzinger said of those who sought pardons. â€œThat is all the more reason to respect those who came here to testify today.â€ Trump last week reiterated his intention to pardon people charged in connection with U.S. Capitol riot if he becomes president again in 2024. â€œAnd if I become president, someday if I decide to do it, I will be looking at them very, very seriously for pardons,â€ Trump said of defendants in the insurrection. Senior Reporter, HuffPost Senior Politics Reporter, HuffPost Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost?

topic: Former U.S. Attorney General Highlights Trump's 'Smoking Gun' In New Jan. 6 Testimony
content:
Senior Reporter, HuffPost Former U.S. Attorney General Eric Holder on Thursday identified what he called the â€œsmoking gunâ€ for criminally charging former President Donald Trump over his conspiracy to overthrow the 2020 presidential election. Appearing Thursday before the House select committee investigating the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol, Richard Donoghue, the acting deputy attorney general in the last weeks of the Trump administration, testified that Trump directed him to â€œjust say the election was corrupt and leave the rest to me and the Republican congressmenâ€ during a Dec. 27, 2020, conversation. Donoghue had written the directive down in his notes and testified that it was an â€œexact quote from the president.â€ â€œThis is the smoking gun. Coupled with other testimony, [it] demonstrates both Trumpâ€™s substantive involvement and corrupt intent, requisite state of mind,â€ tweeted Holder, who served in the Barack Obama administration. Any prosecution of Trump would need to convince a jury that Trump acted with criminal intent to overturn the results of the election, knowing that he had legitimately lost. Trump - â€œJust say the election was corrupt and leave the rest to me and the Republican congressmenâ€. This is the smoking gun. Coupled with other testimony demonstrates both Trumpâ€™s substantive involvement and corrupt intent, requisite state of mind. Donoghue also wrote down that Trump said the Justice Department had â€œan obligation to tell people that this was an illegal, corrupt election.â€ Asked if the Department of Justice had actually found evidence of corruption in the 2020 presidential election, Donoghue said: â€œThere were isolated instances of fraud. None of them came close to calling into question the outcome of the election in any individual state.â€ Thursdayâ€™s hearing focused on efforts by Trump and his allies to pressure Justice Department officials into supporting his scheme to overturn democracy and remain in power. A number of former Justice Department officials have said the Jan. 6 committeeâ€™s hearings have delivered compelling evidence that Trump committed crimes. Donald Ayer, a former deputy attorney general in the George H.W. Bush administration, told The Guardian last week that â€œthe committee hearings have bolstered the need to seriously consider filing criminal charges against Trump.â€ The current attorney general, Merrick Garland, has not yet indicated if Trump is under investigation or if there will be indictments, though he said he would be following the hearings closely. Senior Reporter, HuffPost Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost?

topic: Bob Woodward: 20% Of Republicans Would Now Like To 'Push Trump Off The Cliff'
content:
Trends Reporter, HuffPost Washington Post Watergate journalist Bob Woodward said Thursday on CNN that â€œdramaticâ€ hearings by the House select committee investigating the Jan. 6, 2021, insurrection are having such a significant impact that â€œat least 20% of Republicansâ€ would now like to figuratively â€œpushâ€ Donald Trump â€œoff the cliff.â€ Whether Republicans are watching the hearings â€œor not, a lot of them know that the earth is shaking,â€ Woodwardâ€™s Watergate partner Carl Bernstein added in a panel interview with Anderson Cooper. â€œWhy is the earth shaking? Because â€œboth the committee and the Justice Departmentâ€ know that â€œbefore, during and after Jan. 6,â€ there was a â€œmassive obstruction and conspiracy from the president down ... to not allow the transition of power,â€ Bernstein said. â€œWhat we do know, factually, is the Justice Department has the evidence of this massive conspiracy and cover-up,â€ he added John Dean, a Richard Nixon White House counsel who flipped on him, said the insurrection proceedings are â€œworking much better than the Watergate hearings,â€ with â€œvery effective ... presentations.â€ Theyâ€™re â€œprobably getting to Trump because they are so effective. He appreciates good media.â€ â€œWe forget how protracted the Watergate hearings were,â€ Dean noted. â€œThey were seven months. I didnâ€™t testify for a few hours; I testified for five days, eight hours a day. They were grinding. Woodward agreed that the House select committeeâ€™s hearings are â€œvery dramatic.â€ â€œI think if you can step back, whatâ€™s going on here right now in the Republican Party ... 50% roughly of the Republicans would walk off the cliff for Donald Trump,â€ said Woodward. â€œNow I think at least 20% want to push him off the cliff.â€ And 30% are fixated on simply winning, Woodward noted. â€œIf thereâ€™s one lesson from writing three books about Trump, spending hours interviewing him, there is the lexicon: Win. You have to win. And they want to win,â€ he added. Voters â€œcan make the calculation: Is this a winning hand with Donald Trump or not? And itâ€™s eroding. Whether significant, we will see.â€ The hearings are uncovering â€œmeaty, dramaticâ€ information, Woodward said. topic: Senate Passes Bipartisan Gun Safety Bill A Month After Uvalde Shooting
content:
Senior Politics Reporter, HuffPost WASHINGTON â€• The Senate approved a bipartisan bill on Thursday aimed at curbing gun violence, taking action a month after the horrific mass shooting at an elementary school in Uvalde, Texas, amped up pressure on a response in Congress. Fifteen Republicans joined all Democrats in support of the measure. The House is expected to pass the bill on Friday and send it to President Joe Bidenâ€™s desk for his signature. The legislation, titled the Bipartisan Safer Communities Act, includes modest curbs on obtaining firearms as well as funding to bolster mental health care and school security. Itâ€™s the product of bipartisan compromise after weeks of negotiations led by Sens. Chris Murphy (D-Conn.) and John Cornyn (R-Texas). The measure enhances background checks for people under 21, incentivizes states to adopt â€œred flagâ€ laws, which help remove guns from the hands of people who have been deemed a danger to themselves or others, and prohibits romantic partners convicted of domestic violence who are not married to their victim from getting firearms. It does not include broader restrictions sought by gun control advocates, however, such as bans on assault weapons, raising the minimum age to purchase semi-automatic rifles to 21, mandating safe storage rules at home, or requiring background checks on internet sales and at gun shows. Nevertheless, itâ€™s the most significant federal gun legislation in decades. Democrats and gun control advocacy groups welcomed it as a sign of progress after years of congressional gridlock on dealing with gun violence. â€œThis will become the most significant piece of anti-gun-violence legislation Congress has passed in three decades,â€ Murphy said ahead of the vote. â€œThis bill also has the chance to prove to the weary American public that democracy is not so broken, that it is able to rise to the moment.â€ Cornyn, who was met with a chorus of boos at his state party convention last Friday, acknowledged that Republicans had to go outside their comfort zone. But he said the â€œpotential we have to save lives is worth any sort of concession we might have had to make during negotiations.â€ â€œI donâ€™t believe in doing nothing in the face of what weâ€™ve seen in Uvalde and other communities. Doing nothing is an abdication of our responsibility,â€ he said. Senior Politics Reporter, HuffPost Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost?

topic: FDA Clears COVID Booster Shot For Healthy Kids Ages 5 To 11
content: U.S. regulators on Tuesday authorized a COVID-19 booster shot for healthy 5- to 11-year-olds, hoping an extra vaccine dose will enhance their protection as infections once again creep upward. Everyone 12 and older already was supposed to get one booster dose for the best protection against the newest coronavirus variants â€• and some people, including those 50 and older, can choose a second booster. The Food and Drug Administrationâ€™s authorization now opens a third shot to elementary-age kids, too â€” at least five months after their last dose. There is one more hurdle: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention must decide whether to formally recommend the booster for this age group. The CDCâ€™s scientific advisers are scheduled to meet on Thursday. Pfizerâ€™s shot is the only COVID-19 vaccine available for children of any age in the U.S. Those ages 5 to 11 receive one-third of the dose given to everyone 12 and older. Whether elementary-age children need a booster has been overshadowed by parentsâ€™ outcry to vaccinate even younger tots, those under 5 â€• the only group not yet eligible in the U.S. Both Pfizer and rival Moderna have been studying their shots in the youngest children, and the FDA is expected to evaluate data from one or both companies sometime next month. For the 5- to 11-year-olds, itâ€™s not clear how much demand there will be for boosters. Only about 30% of that age group have had the initial two Pfizer doses since vaccinations opened to them in November. But in a small study, Pfizer found a booster revved up those kidsâ€™ levels of virus-fighting antibodies â€• including those able to fight omicron â€• the same kind of jump adults get from an extra shot. While the coronavirus is more dangerous to adults than to children, youngsters can get severely ill â€• and more than 350 children ages 5 to 11 have died, according to CDCâ€™s count. Adding to public confusion, the CDC estimates 3 out of every 4 U.S. children of all ages have been infected with the coronavirus since the pandemicâ€™s start â€• many of them during the winter omicron wave. Still, health authorities urge vaccination even in people whoâ€™ve previously had COVID-19, to strengthen their protection. Vaccination may not always prevent milder infections, especially as omicron and its siblings are better than some prior variants at slipping past those defenses. But health authorities agree the vaccinations continue to offer strong protection against the worst outcomes of COVID-19, including hospitalization and death.

topic: I Was Told I'm Pregnant. Then I Found Out It's Likely Cancer â€” And I'm Actually Relieved.
content: Guest Writer I sat in stunned silence staring at the ER doctor trying to process what she had just said. I was in an auto accident â€• a distracted driver ran a red light on a clear, sunny day at 12:15 in the afternoon. I went to the emergency room with minor injuries seeking reassurance they werenâ€™t major injuries. I had a CT scan, a couple of X-rays, and I peed in a cup. The doctor had just disclosed the results to me: concussion, contusions, cuts, oh, and Iâ€™m pregnant. There must be some mistake. She looked at me like she was waiting for me to say something, and I looked at her like one of us doesnâ€™t know how menopause works, and it better not be me. (Spoiler alert: It was me.) â€œBut Iâ€™m five years menopausal,â€ I managed to stammer. â€œDo you still have all your organs?â€ she asked. At this point I uttered an expletive and fell back in my chair hitting my already concussed head on the wall. I do have all my organs. She told me to follow up with a blood test at my regular doctor because itâ€™s more accurate. Panic set in. I did what any Floridian would do in an emergency: I went straight to Publix. I bought a twin pack of pregnancy tests and went home. Both of them were negative. It must have been cross-contamination, I told myself. But I go for the blood test anyway. This is no time to be sloppy. The following day at my doctorâ€™s office, she agreed that she can trace my menopause back seven years, and yes, Iâ€™m still â€œpregnantâ€ via urine test. (Dammit!) Bloodwork also came back positive. It was at this point, and with basically every doctor that I talked to over the span of the next two weeks, that I discovered a woman can absolutely get pregnant during menopause â€• they just donâ€™t have any way of knowing. The room was spinning. I thought I might throw up and pass out. The next step was to have an ultrasound, but they couldnâ€™t get me on the schedule for a month. A month. How pregnant am I? If you go by LMP (last menstrual period), Iâ€™m 53 months pregnant. I laugh to myself. I need that ultrasound now. I canâ€™t wait a month! After a few days of making frantic phone calls, it became apparent that the only way I was going to get any answers was to go back to the ER â€• they could order a test and return same-day results. This time I was told there was no detectable pregnancy and that I should have a follow-up appointment for ovarian cancer. Amazingly, the doctor was still not 100% willing to state Iâ€™m not pregnant â€• he gave it a 99.8%. Even as he was discussing the levels of hormones they detected, I know for a fact that Iâ€™m not. They would be detecting a pregnancy that is just hours or days old, so unless I was drugged and raped, itâ€™s something else â€• most likely ovarian cancer. (Iâ€™m still waiting for a final batch of tests that will confirm my diagnosis.) A wave of relief washed over me. The weight of the stress and anxiety Iâ€™d been carrying around suddenly lifted from my shoulders. A faint chorus of angels sang only to me. Yes, cancer was a relief over pregnancy. For starters, I donâ€™t have to choose from one of three horrific options: 1. Keeping a child that I canâ€™t afford and donâ€™t want to raise at this age (spending the next 18 years and at least $250,000 to raise him/her/them). 2. Mentally scarring myself and the kids I do have by putting it up for adoption (sorry â€• we canâ€™t keep your sister). 3. Termination (if thatâ€™s even an option â€• who knows how pregnant I could be). Instead, I have one easy path forward: aggressively treat the cancer. Furthermore, I donâ€™t have to disclose my sex life to anyone, explain how I â€œlet this happen,â€ or deal with any social stigma for being a single, unwed mother. I donâ€™t have to replace my clothes, lose control of my body, or wear my diagnosis for everyone to see, comment on, and rub. Pregnancy is public. Cancer is private â€• no one will know unless I tell them. With cancer, disease or dysfunction, there is no government intervention or regulation restricting care. Nor can the pharmacist embarrass me by refusing to fill my medication for religious reasons. No one claims cancer cells have a right to thrive. I donâ€™t know what the cancer treatment will entail, but I do know that with every previous pregnancy, the morning sickness was debilitating. I threw up 15 hours a day, for weeks straight. I would lie on the cold tile of the bathroom floor for proximity to the toilet and the cooling relief from the heat of my face, clutching an ultrasound photo of my twins, trying to convince myself it was going to be worth this hell to produce two healthy babies. Pregnancy isnâ€™t easy, even if we somehow manage to make it look effortless. Donâ€™t get me wrong: I know that my cancer might be fatal. But so might a pregnancy â€• especially if Roe v. Wade is overturned. I almost died in my last one: It was heterotopic. As I type this, some states are trying to make surviving that illegal. The U.S. already has the highest maternal mortality rate of the developed world and that was when we had access to complete health care. I talk to my twins about that. They would have lost me (and their little brother) at age 11 if it was illegal to remove the wayward fetus stuck to my fallopian tube. â€œRight to lifeâ€ somehow doesnâ€™t include the momâ€™s life anymore (or any other fetuses in a multi-gestational pregnancy). As women and people with uteruses, we must now consider whether our partnerâ€™s orgasm is worth our lives. With Roe gone, there would be no distinction between consenting to sex and consenting to conception. There is no longer any room for error. When and where our partner orgasms is the only controllable part of the equation â€• and the control is not ours. Nor can we control ovulation, conception, implantation, gestation or birth â€• the only part of the biological process we have any say over is sex. And sometimes, through force or coercion, we donâ€™t even get a say in that. Yet we are held completely accountable for whatever may come from the act. It is our lives that will be forever changed. Men might have to pay child support. Rapists might go to jail. The baby is always our burden. The message the government is sending is that it doesnâ€™t matter what you do or where you are in life: As a woman, there is no greater contribution to society than your ability to reproduce. You could be a scientist working on treating or curing COVID, a Supreme Court justice (looking at you, Amy Coney Barrett), a student, a cancer patient, a woman being beaten within inches of her life on a weekly basis, a trans person mid-transition â€• it doesnâ€™t matter: You are expected to birth a child whether you can or not, whether you should or not, whether you want to or not, and whether you consented to or not. At what point did women cease to be autonomous people promised life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness and start to become assets of the government tasked to reproduce? Iâ€™m afraid to have sex now. I know that I have had difficult pregnancies. I know that I might not be allowed to survive the same pregnancy as my last one if Roe is overturned. And now I know that I can get pregnant even through menopause and back-up birth control, and if I do, I wonâ€™t have any idea until the vomiting starts. By then it will be too late. Itâ€™s the stuff of nightmares. Cancer might be fatal, but during my heterotopic pregnancy it only took four weeks after conception (six weeks of a pregnancy!) for my fallopian tube to rupture, causing internal bleeding so badly that doctors couldnâ€™t see my organs because of all the blood spilling into my abdomen. If Roe is overturned and some trigger laws go into effect, some women will find themselves with a four-week expectation of life. I have twins graduating college in December and I really want to be here for that. How could I possibly engage in behavior that might kill me before I see that milestone? As sick as it may be, yes, when compared to pregnancy, the possibility of having ovarian cancer is a relief. Monica Fox has an MBA from the University of Florida and has spent 17 years in nonprofit management. She is the proud mom to three genius sons. topic: These Inclusive Bandages Match A Variety Of Skin Tones -- And You Can Buy Them Online
content: Shopping Writer at HuffPost As a child, I was no stranger to the occasional scrape, bump and bruise thanks to my adventurous nature. My parents basically kept a box of bandages and Neosporin on standby whenever I played outside. And even though Iâ€™ve traded playgrounds for coffee shops and scooters for a subway, my slight clumsiness still means I end up with the occasional random scratch on my body. But two things that Iâ€™ve become hyper-aware in recent years, after multiple instances of violence and discrimination against my community, are representation and inclusion. And despite bandages being such a minuscule aspect of everyday life, putting on one that actually matches my skin tone means more to me than I ever thought it would. Having a tiny object that most people will wear at some point during their lives come in colors other than the â€œdefaultâ€ beige makes me feel seen (literally) and allows me to deter attention from wounds like bandages are meant to do. Though we still have a way to go with more inclusive bandages becoming available to match everyoneâ€™s skin tone, especially in doctorsâ€™ offices, Iâ€™m excited about the ones that exist already online. Brands like Tru-Colour, Band-Aid and BioSwiss all make bandages in various shades of brown (even deep brown!) so that children, teens and adults of all skin tones can have experience a real â€œnudeâ€ bandage. topic: U.S. Government Offering Twice As Many COVID Test Kits Via Mail
content: The U.S. government has doubled the number of COVID-19 test kits people can order for their household. The government previously limited households to one order of four at-home rapid test kits, however, households can now order eight kits. The kits come in two packages and will be shipped free, according to the U.S. Postal Service. People who have ordered previous test kits from the program are eligible for another round as well. You can click here to order the kits via the USPS website. The increased distribution comes as COVID cases in the U.S. have seen an uptick in recent weeks. The seven-day rolling average of cases on Sunday showed 150% more reported cases than in the month prior, according to data from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The average was the highest recorded by the CDC in almost three months. The number of reported COVID hospitalizations has also risen. Last weekâ€™s seven-day rolling average of hospitalizations increased 8.3% from the previous week, according to the CDC. COVID-related deaths tracked by the CDC have continued to drop. The CDC reported 40 deaths due to COVID on Sunday, a drop since the most recent omicron wave began at the start of the year. Earlier this month, experts noted the appearance of a new â€œhighly transmissibleâ€ omicron subvariant, BA.2.12.1. The subvariantâ€™s presence has roughly doubled in the past month among reported cases, according to CDC data. The new omicron subvariant was reported in 42.6% of cases for the week ending May 7, the last week of data reported by the CDC. This is compared with the subvariantâ€™s 18.5% prevalence in cases reported for the week ending April 16. After Vice President Kamala Harris tested positive for COVID-19 in late April, White House COVID-19 response coordinator Dr. Ashish Jha warned Americans about the new variant. â€œIt is going to be hard to ensure that no one gets COVID in America,â€ he said.

topic: Speaker Nancy Pelosi Slams Supreme Court As 'Dangerous To Freedoms In Our Country'
content:
Trends Reporter, HuffPost House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) took the gloves off Sunday to blast the U.S. Supreme Court as â€œdangerous to families, to freedoms in our country.â€ â€œWho would have ever suspected a creature like Donald Trump would become president, waving a list of judges he would appoint ... getting the support of the far-right and appointing those anti-freedom justices to the court?â€ she asked. Pelosi targeted the draft opinion by Justice Samuel Alito gutting Roe v. Wade that was leaked earlier this month. But she also fears it marks the beginning of a wholesale dismantling of freedoms by the aggressively conservative court. â€œBeware in terms of marriage equality, beware in terms of other aspects,â€ she warned in an interview CNNâ€™s â€œState of the Union.â€ â€œUnderstand this,â€ she added about Alitoâ€™s decision, which is not yet final. â€œThis is not just about terminating a pregnancy. This is about contraception, family planning.â€ The decision rocks a â€œplace where freedom and the kitchen table, issues of Americaâ€™s families, come together,â€ she added. â€œWhat are the decisions that a family makes. What about contraception for young people? Itâ€™s beyond a particular situation. Itâ€™s massive in terms of contraception, in vitro fertilization, a womanâ€™s right to decide,â€ she said. Pelosi said Republicans have stymied Democrats in efforts to pass a federal law to safeguard reproductive rights. She called on Democrats to mobilize and vote in midterm elections to help eradicate the damage by the conservative justices, including the three named by Trump: Neil Gorsuch, Brett Kavanaugh and Amy Coney Barrett. â€œThe genius of our founders was to have a Constitution that enabled freedom to expand,â€ said Pelosi. â€œThis is the first time the court has taken back a freedom that was defined by precedent and respect for privacy.â€ In an interview Sunday on ABC News, Pelosi condemned the horrific fatal shooting of 10 people at a Buffalo supermarket Saturday. Almost all of the victims were Black. â€œOur hearts are so sad for the families affected by this,â€ she told George Stephanopoulos. â€œOf course, we are trying to do something about gun violence,â€ Pelosi added, leaving unsaid the nearly insurmountable opposition to reeling in guns from the Republican Party. topic: North Korea Reports 8 Deaths As Kim Laments Virus Response
content: SEOUL, South Korea (AP) â€” North Korea on Monday reported 8 new deaths and 392,920 more people with fevers amid a growing COVID-19 outbreak as leader Kim Jong Un blasted officials over delays in medicine deliveries and ordered his military to get involved in the pandemic response in the countryâ€™s capital, Pyongyang. The Northâ€™s emergency anti-virus headquarters said more than 1.2 million people fell ill amid a rapid spread of fever since late April and about 564,860 are currently under quarantine. The eight new deaths reported in the 24 hours through 6 p.m. Sunday brought its death toll to 50. State media didnâ€™t specify how many of the fever cases and deaths were confirmed as COVID-19 cases. Experts say North Korea likely lacks testing supplies and equipment to confirm coronavirus infections in large numbers and is mostly relying on isolating people with symptoms at shelters. Experts say the failure to slow the virus could have dire consequences for North Korea, considering its poor health care system. Its population of 26 million people are believed to be mostly unvaccinated after their government had shunned millions of shots offered by the U.N.-backed COVAX distribution program, likely over concerns related to international monitoring requirements. North Korea acknowledged its first COVID-19 outbreak last Thursday when it announced that an unspecified number of people in Pyongyang tested positive for the omicron outbreak. It had previously held for more than two years to a widely doubted claim of a perfect record keeping out the virus that has spread to nearly every place in the world. Kim during a ruling party Politburo meeting on Sunday criticized government and health officials over what he portrayed as a botched pandemic response, saying state medicine supplies arenâ€™t being supplied to pharmacies in time because of their â€œirresponsible work attitudeâ€ and lack of organization, the Northâ€™s official Korean Central News Agency said. The Politburo had issued an emergency order to immediately release and quickly distribute state medicine reserves and for pharmacies to switch over to 24-hour shifts, but Kim said such steps werenâ€™t being properly implemented. Kim ordered that the medical units of his military to get involved in stabilizing the supply of medicine in Pyongyang, KCNA said. State media had previously said a workforce of more than 1.3 million â€“ including public health officials, teachers and medical university students â€“ were mobilized to find people with fevers or other symptoms so that they could be quarantined. North Koreaâ€™s claim of a perfect record in keeping out the virus for 2 1/2 years was widely doubted. But its extremely strict border closure, large-scale quarantines and propaganda that stressed anti-virus controls as a matter of â€œnational existenceâ€ may have staved off a huge outbreak until now. While North Korea could suffer huge fatalities if it doesnâ€™t quickly receive international shipments of medical supplies, itâ€™s not immediately clear whether the Northâ€™s admission of the outbreak communicates a willingness to receive outside help. Rival South Korea has offered to send vaccines and other supplies, but Seoul officials say the North has not made such a request. But some experts say Kimâ€™s comments last week during another Politburo meeting, where he praised Chinaâ€™s pandemic response and urged his officials to learn from it, suggest that the North could be more willing to accept help from its major ally. Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Zhao Lijian said last week that Beijing was ready to offer North Korea help but said he had no information about any such request being made. Even as he called for stronger preventive measures to slow the spread of COVID-19, Kim has also stressed that the countryâ€™s economic goals should be met, which likely means huge groups will continue to gather at agricultural, industrial and construction sites. While accelerating his missile tests in a brinkmanship aimed at pressuring the United States for economic and security concessions, Kim has been grappling with domestic challenges at home as pandemic-related difficulties unleashed further shock on an economy broken by decades of mismanagement and crippling U.S.-led sanctions against the North, pushing him to perhaps the toughest moment since he took power in 2011.

topic: Rep. Elise Stefanik's Staff Reportedly Backs Off Her 'Pedo Grifter' Theory On Formula Shortage
content:
Trends Reporter, HuffPost After critics pummeled Rep. Elise Stefanik (R-N.Y.) for nonsensically blaming the â€œusual pedo griftersâ€ for Americaâ€™s infant formula shortage, her office reportedly insisted that is not what she meant at all. A staffer for the extremist lawmaker said she wasnâ€™t blaming â€œpedophileâ€ grifters, but intended â€œpedoâ€ to mean â€œchildren,â€ writer Parker Molloy reported Saturday â€” which still makes no sense. â€œPedoâ€ or pedophile is a well-known dogwhistle to QAnon conspiracy theorists who are baselessy convinced â€œpedoâ€ Democrats are running an international child sex-trafficking operation. The weird contortion after Stefanikâ€™s outrageous Twitter post was captured in a recorded phone call to the lawmakerâ€™s office by an unidentified â€œconstituent,â€ Molloy reported in â€œThe Present Age.â€ Neither Stefanik nor a representative could immediately be reached for comment, and HuffPost could not confirm the speaker on the recording was a Stefanik staffer. But the recorded voice appeared to be identical to one on an answering machine responding to calls to a Stefanik constituent office. The unidentified caller asks who the â€œusual pedo griftersâ€ are that Stefanik refers to in her tweet. â€œFirst off, this is her personal Twitter. Just have to note that,â€ the staffer responds, pointing out that the office had received a number of calls about the issue. â€œAnd No. 2, â€˜pedoâ€™ is not short for â€˜pedophile, it is â€˜pedo,â€™ as in â€˜children.â€™â€ â€œSo these are people who are grifting their children?â€ asks the confused caller. â€œHow are they grifting their children? Or are they children who are grifting?â€ The person responds: â€œNo, not children who are grifting ... people who are grifting on behalf of children.â€ When asked to explain how that works, the staffer says he â€œcanâ€™t really analyze it.â€ The full phone call can be heard here: A staffer on Friday gave a slightly different version of â€œpedo griftersâ€ to The Independent, saying they were Republicans in The Lincoln Project â€” but apparently didnâ€™t even try to begin to explain that one. Mediaite was also told Friday, apparently without explanation: â€œPedo grifters refers to the Lincoln Project.â€ The Lincoln Project is a PAC founded and run by Republicans critical of Donald Trump. There is nothing linking the Lincoln Project to the infant formula shortage â€” or to pedophilia. Critics on Friday warned that Stefanikâ€™s irresponsible â€œpedoâ€ tweet could trigger violence against imagined enemies. A gunman opened fire in 2016 in a Washington, D.C., pizzeria that was baselessly identified as a headquarters for a supposed child-trafficking operation. No one was injured. The â€œPizzagateâ€ gunman was sentenced to four years in prison. "usual pedo grifters" is straight-up QAnon rhetoric that led a gunman to open fire in a DC pizza place believing there were children trapped in a non-existent basement.Anyone claiming to legitimately care about children should stop using rhetoric that will get people killed. https://t.co/cl1IkYEkMs Stefanik was also ripped for her heartless call in her tweet to deny infant formula to immigrant babies being processed or detained in federal facilities. The government is required by law to provide necessities in such situations. #EliseStarvefanik the new leader of the pro starvation caucus. https://t.co/Y1vV3AqGoQ Stefanik blames the Biden administration for the current shortage of infant formula in America. The administration does not manufacture formula; itâ€™s created and sold by three major companies, which have little competition and a powerful control of the market. The shortage was triggered in part by pandemic-related supply chain issues combined with a massive safety recall by the largest formula producer, Abbott Nutrition, which was forced to close its Michigan plant earlier this year due to contamination concerns. topic: Federal Judge Issues Injunction Against Alabama Law Criminalizing Gender-Affirming Care For Minors
content:
Trends Reporter, HuffPost A federal judge in Alabama issued a preliminary injunction Friday blocking most provisions of a controversial new state law criminalizing gender-affirming health care for minors. The court ruled that the ban on measures such as hormone therapy and puberty blockers appears to be discriminatory and violates the constitutional rights of both parents and children. The law making gender-affirming health care a felony went into effect in Alabama on Monday. â€œParent Plaintiffs have a fundamental right to direct the medical care of their children,â€ said the ruling by U.S. District Judge Liles C. Burke of the Middle District of Alabama, Northern Division. â€œThis right includes the more specific right to treat their children with transitioning medications subject to medically accepted standards. The Act infringes on that right.â€ Citing legal precedents, Burke, who was appointed by Donald Trump, noted that â€œa parentâ€™s right to â€˜make decisions concerning the care, custody and control of their childrenâ€™ is one of the â€˜oldest of fundamental liberty interestsâ€™ recognized by the Supreme Court.â€ Arguments by the state fell flat. Defendants, for example, produced no â€œcredible evidence to show that transitional medications are â€˜experimental,â€™â€ as claimed, Burke noted. The stateâ€™s justifications for the law are â€œhypothesized, not exceedingly persuasive,â€ the judge added. Burke issued the injunction after concluding that the â€œimminent threat of harm to Parent Plaintiffs and Minor Plaintiffs â€” i.e., severe physical and/or psychological harmâ€ while the case is being argued â€œoutweighs the harm the State will suffer from the injunction.â€ The judge did allow several other provisions of the law to remain in place, including a ban on gender-affirming surgeries for minors. It's not a complete win. The court still allows for the surgery ban to stay in effect, as well as the forced outing provisions. These are still extremely harmful to trans kids but their medical care will not be criminalized. pic.twitter.com/uaK2BcjfUj Shannon Minter, legal director of the National Center for Lesbian Rights, one of the groups that sued Alabama over the law, tweeted Friday that he was â€œso relieved and thrilled by this decision in our case,â€ adding: â€œThis is a powerful opinion.â€ He told the Los Angeles Blade the ruling was a major â€œvictory for compassion and common sense and a much needed antidote to the tidal wave of hostile legislation targeting these youth. Thanks to this decision, kids in Alabama can now continue to receive this lifesaving care, and their doctors cannot be prosecuted simply for doing their jobs,â€ Minter added. Dr. Morissa Ladinsky, a pediatrician who founded a Birmingham medical team that treats children with gender dysphoria, told The Associated Press the judgeâ€™s decision is a â€œhuge relief for transgender children and their families.â€ The courtâ€™s decision â€œrecognizes that this is well established care that has been endorsed by 22 major medical associations. This decision will ensure transgender children in Alabama, and beyond, can continue to receive this evidence-based life-saving care,â€ she added. topic: Margaret Atwood Once Thought 'The Handmaid's Tale' Was 'Too Far-Fetched.' No Longer.
content:
Trends Reporter, HuffPost Author Margaret Atwood revealed Friday that she initially put off writing her horrifying dystopian novel â€œThe Handmaidâ€™s Taleâ€ because she thought it was â€œtoo far-fetched.â€ But after the leak of a draft Supreme Court opinion, sheâ€™ll never feel that way again. â€œSilly me. Theocratic dictatorships do not lie only in the distant past: There are a number of them on the planet today. What is to prevent the United States from becoming one of them?â€ she asked in a column published Friday in The Atlantic. In Atwoodâ€™s novel, women in America are used as reproductive slaves, strictly governed by a theocratic dictatorship directed by men. Atwoodâ€™s model was based on 17th century New England Puritan religious rules and jurisprudence â€” and imported to the U.S. Supreme Court Justice Samuel Alito also turned to the 1600s for justifying his leaked opinion that would gut the 1973 Roe v. Wade ruling that made abortion legal, reaching beyond the issues raised in a challenge to a Mississippi anti-abortion law. He cited several times the English jurist Matthew Hale, who opposed abortions â€” and executed â€œwitches.â€ The leaked opinion (which hasnâ€™t been finalized) would â€œoverthrow settled law of 50 years on the grounds that abortion is not mentioned ... . True enough,â€ Atwood conceded. â€œThe Constitution has nothing to say about womenâ€™s reproductive health. But the original document does not mention women at all.â€ Women â€œwere deliberately excluded from the franchise,â€ she added, referring to the fledgling nation. Only men would no longer be taxed â€œwithout representationâ€ or be ruled without â€œconsent.â€ Women were barred from voting until 1920. â€œWomen were nonpersons in U.S. law for a lot longer than they have been persons,â€ Atwood chillingly noted. â€œIf we start overthrowing settled law using Justice Samuel Alitoâ€™s justifications, why not repeal votes for women?â€ As for banning abortion, the belief about when life begins is based on personal or religious beliefs (some religions, for example, believe life begins at birth or that a pregnant womanâ€™s life is the existing life that must be protected). Now, in Alitoâ€™s opinion, â€œThat which is a sin within a certain set of religious beliefs is to be made a crime for all,â€ Atwood wrote. Yet the Constitution demands that â€œCongress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof.â€ If a religion allows abortion, how can a different religion restrict it for those with different beliefs? â€œIt ought to be simple: If you believe in â€˜ensoulmentâ€™ at conception, you should not get an abortion, because to do so is a sin within your religion. If you do not so believe, you should not â€” under the Constitution â€” be bound by the religious beliefs of others,â€ Atwood argued. The Alito opinion â€œlooks to be well on the way to establishing a state religion,â€ Atwood added, and is turning back to the 17th century, when Colonial women were burned at the stake based on religious evidence. â€œIf Justice Alito wants you to be governed by the laws of the 17th Century, you should take a close look at that century,â€ Atwood warned. â€œIs that when you want to live?â€ Check out the full column here. topic: Twitter Users Mock Matt Gaetz's 1st Tweet After His Pardon Request Is Made Public
content:
Senior Reporter, HuffPost Rep. Matt Gaetz (R-Fla.) became a victim of â€œpardon bombingâ€ Thursday on Twitter. It happened after the House select committee investigating the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol revealed that the lawmaker was one of at least five members of Congress who attempted to get pardons from then-President Donald Trump for their roles in helping Trump attempt to overturn the 2020 presidential election. But Gaetz wanted his pardon to be a lot broader than his role in Trumpâ€™s election fraud, according to Cassidy Hutchinson, a former aide to White House chief of staff Mark Meadows. She told the committee that Gaetz had been pushing for a pardon since early December, according to Business Insider. Former White House senior adviser Eric Herschmann told the committee that the â€œgeneral toneâ€ of the pardon request revolved around the idea that â€œWe may get prosecuted because we were defensive of, you know, the presidentâ€™s positions on these things.â€ However, Herschmann noted that the pardon Gaetz was angling for may have been intended to also protect him from the sex trafficking investigation swirling around him. â€œThe pardon that he was discussing, requesting, was as broad as you could describe, from... the beginning of time up until today, for any and all things,â€ Herschmann told the committee. After the revelation, Gaetz posted on Twitter to accuse the committee of being â€œan unconstitutional political sideshowâ€ that is â€œrapidly losing the interest of the American people and now resorts to siccing federal law enforcement on political opponents.â€ The January 6 Committee is an unconstitutional political sideshow. topic: Angry Trump Again Demands The Impossible From Jan. 6 Panel After Riveting Hearing
content:
Trends Reporter, HuffPost Former President Donald Trumpâ€™s reaction Thursday to another powerful day of testimony before the House select committee investigating the U.S. Capitol riot was to again demand the impossible: evidence of a rigged presidential election. â€œThe only thing not discussed by the Unselects, in any way, shape, or form, is the irrefutable evidence of massive and totally pervasive ELECTION FRAUD & IRREGULARITIES which took place during the 2020 Presidential Election. They refuse to go there,â€ he posted. It wasnâ€™t discussed because it never happened. A litany of testimony from former Department of Justice officials on Thursday â€” and in earlier sessions â€” refuted Trumpâ€™s â€œirrefutableâ€ claims. Trump appears to be ignoring the information in the hearings the same way he ignored responses from his Justice Department, various state officials and U.S. Attorney General William Barr: The claims of a rigged election were baseless. A number of specific claims have been refuted in detail. Trump insisted on Truth Social that it would be â€œimpossibleâ€ for the Jan. 6 hearing to â€œrefute or challenge that which would be put before them. To the Unselects, I ask, LET US PUT ON THE EVIDENCE STATE BY STATE.â€ Neither he nor his supporters have offered any such evidence. Arizona House Speaker Rusty Bowers (R) testified Tuesday that Trump lawyer Rudy Giuliani asked him to hold up electoral votes because â€œ200,000 illegal immigrantsâ€ and more than 5,000 â€œdead peopleâ€ voted in the state. Bowers told Giuliani he wanted names and was promised he would get them, he said. Despite repeated requests, he was never given a single name, Bowers testified. Last week, Trump noted on Truth Social that the â€œUnselect Committee refuses to debate the Election results, the reason for the massive crowd on January 6th, because they canâ€™t.â€ In a separate post Thursday, Trump asked: â€œWhat about the massive ballot stuffing shown ... by the highly respected and credible Patriots of Truth (2000 Mules).â€ He was referring to a discredited â€œdocumentary,â€ which elicited a derisive laugh from the former attorney general during Barrâ€™s testimony. â€œI suppose thatâ€™s OK by the Unselects? Such lies!â€ Trump added in his post. Trends Reporter, HuffPost Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost?

topic: At Least 5 Members Of Congress Asked Trump For Pardons, According To Jan. 6 Committee
content:
Senior Reporter, HuffPost Senior Politics Reporter, HuffPost WASHINGTON â€• The House select committee investigating the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol named five additional Republican Congress members who sought pardons from President Donald Trump. The requests stemmed from their involvement in Trumpâ€™s schemes to try to subvert the 2020 presidential election, which Trump insisted he won despite losing by several million votes. The committee previously revealed that Rep. Scott Perry (R-Pa.) sought a presidential pardon, something the congressman denied. During Thursdayâ€™s public hearing on Capitol Hill, witnesses close to the Trump White House said in previously recorded interviews that Republican Reps. Matt Gaetz (Fla.), Mo Brooks (Ala.), Andy Biggs (Ariz.) and Louie Gohmert (Texas) also asked for pardons. â€œThe pardon he was requesting was as broad as you can describe ... for any and all things,â€ former Trump White House lawyer Eric Herschmann said of Gaetz in video testimony that the committee played on Thursday. Cassidy Hutchinson, an aide to former White House chief of staff Mark Meadows, confirmed to the committee that Gaetz and the other GOP members of Congress sought pardons. â€œMr. Gaetz and Mr. Brooks I know both advocated for there to be a blanket pardon,â€ Hutchinson said. In a statement after the hearing, a spokesperson for Brooks said the congressman only wanted a pardon in case Democrats abused the justice system and started â€œprosecuting and jailingâ€ their political opponents. Brooks also released an image of the email he sent to the White House in December, on behalf of himself and Gaetz, recommending that the president give â€œgeneral (all purpose) pardonsâ€ to every Republican who voted to overturn the election after the Jan. 6 riot. In a speech at Trumpâ€™s rally before the attack on the U.S. Capitol, Brooks said, â€œToday is the day American patriots start taking down names and kicking ass.â€ Hutchinson said that she heard Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-Ga.) also asked for a pardon but that she didnâ€™t hear it directly. â€œI heard that she asked the White House counselâ€™s office for a pardon,â€ she said. â€œThe only reason I know to ask for a pardon is because you think youâ€™ve committed a crime,â€ Jan. 6 committee member Adam Kinzinger (R-Ill.) said. In a tweet after the hearing, Greene didnâ€™t exactly deny that she had asked for a pardon but said, â€œSaying â€˜I heardâ€™ means you donâ€™t know. Spreading gossip and lies is exactly what the January 6th Witch Hunt Committee is all about.â€ Thursdayâ€™s hearing featured testimony from former Justice Department officials Jeffrey Rosen and Richard Donoghue, as well as Office of Legal Counsel director Steven Engel, who described Trumpâ€™s efforts to throw out the election despite their objections that doing so would be unconstitutional and contrary to the will of the American voters. Donoghue, who was then acting deputy attorney general, testified that when Trump threatened to replace Rosen as the acting attorney general with Jeffrey Clark, an assistant attorney general in the departmentâ€™s Environment and Natural Resources Division, he was told the change would spark mass resignations in the Justice Department. â€œMr. President, I would resign immediately. I would not work one minute for this guy,â€ Donoghue said he told Trump, referring to Clark. During the Jan. 6 committee hearing, Kinzinger described how Perry lobbied the White House to elevate Clark in the Justice Department in order to gain his help in subverting the election. Perry improperly brought Clark to a White House meeting and texted White House chief of staff Mark Meadows, urging him to appoint Clark to a role with â€œthe authority to enforce what needs to be done.â€ Perry denied seeking a pardon earlier this month. â€œThe notion that I ever sought a Presidential pardon for myself or other Members of Congress is an absolute, shameless, and soulless lie,â€ Perry said on Twitter. Kinzinger deliberately juxtaposed testimony about pardon-seekers with the live testimony from Justice Department officials who refused to do Trumpâ€™s bidding. â€œThey knew that every bit of what they did was a lie and it was wrong,â€ Kinzinger said of those who sought pardons. â€œThat is all the more reason to respect those who came here to testify today.â€ Trump last week reiterated his intention to pardon people charged in connection with U.S. Capitol riot if he becomes president again in 2024. â€œAnd if I become president, someday if I decide to do it, I will be looking at them very, very seriously for pardons,â€ Trump said of defendants in the insurrection. Senior Reporter, HuffPost Senior Politics Reporter, HuffPost Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost?

topic: Former U.S. Attorney General Highlights Trump's 'Smoking Gun' In New Jan. 6 Testimony
content:
Senior Reporter, HuffPost Former U.S. Attorney General Eric Holder on Thursday identified what he called the â€œsmoking gunâ€ for criminally charging former President Donald Trump over his conspiracy to overthrow the 2020 presidential election. Appearing Thursday before the House select committee investigating the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol, Richard Donoghue, the acting deputy attorney general in the last weeks of the Trump administration, testified that Trump directed him to â€œjust say the election was corrupt and leave the rest to me and the Republican congressmenâ€ during a Dec. 27, 2020, conversation. Donoghue had written the directive down in his notes and testified that it was an â€œexact quote from the president.â€ â€œThis is the smoking gun. Coupled with other testimony, [it] demonstrates both Trumpâ€™s substantive involvement and corrupt intent, requisite state of mind,â€ tweeted Holder, who served in the Barack Obama administration. Any prosecution of Trump would need to convince a jury that Trump acted with criminal intent to overturn the results of the election, knowing that he had legitimately lost. Trump - â€œJust say the election was corrupt and leave the rest to me and the Republican congressmenâ€. This is the smoking gun. Coupled with other testimony demonstrates both Trumpâ€™s substantive involvement and corrupt intent, requisite state of mind. Donoghue also wrote down that Trump said the Justice Department had â€œan obligation to tell people that this was an illegal, corrupt election.â€ Asked if the Department of Justice had actually found evidence of corruption in the 2020 presidential election, Donoghue said: â€œThere were isolated instances of fraud. None of them came close to calling into question the outcome of the election in any individual state.â€ Thursdayâ€™s hearing focused on efforts by Trump and his allies to pressure Justice Department officials into supporting his scheme to overturn democracy and remain in power. A number of former Justice Department officials have said the Jan. 6 committeeâ€™s hearings have delivered compelling evidence that Trump committed crimes. Donald Ayer, a former deputy attorney general in the George H.W. Bush administration, told The Guardian last week that â€œthe committee hearings have bolstered the need to seriously consider filing criminal charges against Trump.â€ The current attorney general, Merrick Garland, has not yet indicated if Trump is under investigation or if there will be indictments, though he said he would be following the hearings closely. topic: Bob Woodward: 20% Of Republicans Would Now Like To 'Push Trump Off The Cliff'
content:
Trends Reporter, HuffPost Washington Post Watergate journalist Bob Woodward said Thursday on CNN that â€œdramaticâ€ hearings by the House select committee investigating the Jan. 6, 2021, insurrection are having such a significant impact that â€œat least 20% of Republicansâ€ would now like to figuratively â€œpushâ€ Donald Trump â€œoff the cliff.â€ Whether Republicans are watching the hearings â€œor not, a lot of them know that the earth is shaking,â€ Woodwardâ€™s Watergate partner Carl Bernstein added in a panel interview with Anderson Cooper. â€œWhy is the earth shaking? Because â€œboth the committee and the Justice Departmentâ€ know that â€œbefore, during and after Jan. 6,â€ there was a â€œmassive obstruction and conspiracy from the president down ... to not allow the transition of power,â€ Bernstein said. â€œWhat we do know, factually, is the Justice Department has the evidence of this massive conspiracy and cover-up,â€ he added John Dean, a Richard Nixon White House counsel who flipped on him, said the insurrection proceedings are â€œworking much better than the Watergate hearings,â€ with â€œvery effective ... presentations.â€ Theyâ€™re â€œprobably getting to Trump because they are so effective. He appreciates good media.â€ â€œWe forget how protracted the Watergate hearings were,â€ Dean noted. â€œThey were seven months. I didnâ€™t testify for a few hours; I testified for five days, eight hours a day. They were grinding. Woodward agreed that the House select committeeâ€™s hearings are â€œvery dramatic.â€ â€œI think if you can step back, whatâ€™s going on here right now in the Republican Party ... 50% roughly of the Republicans would walk off the cliff for Donald Trump,â€ said Woodward. â€œNow I think at least 20% want to push him off the cliff.â€ And 30% are fixated on simply winning, Woodward noted. â€œIf thereâ€™s one lesson from writing three books about Trump, spending hours interviewing him, there is the lexicon: Win. You have to win. And they want to win,â€ he added. Voters â€œcan make the calculation: Is this a winning hand with Donald Trump or not? And itâ€™s eroding. Whether significant, we will see.â€ The hearings are uncovering â€œmeaty, dramaticâ€ information, Woodward said. topic: Senate Passes Bipartisan Gun Safety Bill A Month After Uvalde Shooting
content:
Senior Politics Reporter, HuffPost WASHINGTON â€• The Senate approved a bipartisan bill on Thursday aimed at curbing gun violence, taking action a month after the horrific mass shooting at an elementary school in Uvalde, Texas, amped up pressure on a response in Congress. Fifteen Republicans joined all Democrats in support of the measure. The House is expected to pass the bill on Friday and send it to President Joe Bidenâ€™s desk for his signature. The legislation, titled the Bipartisan Safer Communities Act, includes modest curbs on obtaining firearms as well as funding to bolster mental health care and school security. Itâ€™s the product of bipartisan compromise after weeks of negotiations led by Sens. Chris Murphy (D-Conn.) and John Cornyn (R-Texas). The measure enhances background checks for people under 21, incentivizes states to adopt â€œred flagâ€ laws, which help remove guns from the hands of people who have been deemed a danger to themselves or others, and prohibits romantic partners convicted of domestic violence who are not married to their victim from getting firearms. It does not include broader restrictions sought by gun control advocates, however, such as bans on assault weapons, raising the minimum age to purchase semi-automatic rifles to 21, mandating safe storage rules at home, or requiring background checks on internet sales and at gun shows. Nevertheless, itâ€™s the most significant federal gun legislation in decades. Democrats and gun control advocacy groups welcomed it as a sign of progress after years of congressional gridlock on dealing with gun violence. â€œThis will become the most significant piece of anti-gun-violence legislation Congress has passed in three decades,â€ Murphy said ahead of the vote. â€œThis bill also has the chance to prove to the weary American public that democracy is not so broken, that it is able to rise to the moment.â€ Cornyn, who was met with a chorus of boos at his state party convention last Friday, acknowledged that Republicans had to go outside their comfort zone. But he said the â€œpotential we have to save lives is worth any sort of concession we might have had to make during negotiations.â€ â€œI donâ€™t believe in doing nothing in the face of what weâ€™ve seen in Uvalde and other communities. Doing nothing is an abdication of our responsibility,â€ he said. Senior Politics Reporter, HuffPost Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost?
